author: austenballard

Y'all I am half dead, fresh out of hospital and fully nuked off medications so please forgive the frankness and possible incoherence, but 

I just want to take a moment to appreciate the quality of discussion that happens in this server, and really thank each and every one of you, @oaklandmatt , @admin, @moderator, and everyone else for contributing to what is fast becoming one of my favorite places on the internet.

author: cian riordan
content:
While the 'science is settled' argument is often used to shut down discussion, it's also rooted in the idea that certain ideas have reached some form of scientific consensus -- usually rooted in findings more exhaustive than off the cuff anecdotal evidence. As somebody with a science background myself, my issue with Jon's claim is that its not rooted in any sort of methodical process. And now kids on the internet get fueled with the idea that one DAW might sound better than another -- instead of focusing on things that make far more of a difference in their productions/mixes/masters/etc.

EDIT: I Have no doubt that if the same person mixed the same song in two different DAWs that they’d come to very different results. But that’s all inherent to the workflow, not to the physics or limitations of that particular DAW.

author: bobby k
content: In the midst of a kinda unique side quest at the moment - label pulls me in at an hourly rate with an artist (and good friend) that I’ve mixed for many times because the production sessions were such a mess that they felt like they couldn’t even finish the records until some light mixing and organization took place. Songs spread out between multiple project files, DAWs, laptops…vocals tracked to mp3s with the ~50ms delay thing…Some of these producers templates…brilliant stuff. Saw one vocal travel through maybe 7 or 8 auxes and hit probably 4 different rvox’s along the way. It was like a labyrinth of signal flow that was nearly impossible to follow (and once I deleted half the auxes and waves plugins, it started to come back to life). In short they’re having me un-mix it, hand it back for some more production, then do the final mixes later this year. A true testament to the importance of organization and more importantly minimalist, straight forward session files. I wonder how often this need comes up and how feasible it is to be involved ahead of the handoff as a mixer these days. And before you frown at me for griping, this is an absolutely incredible project, many insanely talented musicians I respect. Very right brained, free flowing group. So it felt cool to be able to play more of a part on the project as the more left brained participant and see the stress relief happen in real time.

author: Skyler Young
content:
I’m in a discord  with a bunch of genius indie plug-in developers where they all show their crazy dual screen setups, well designed shortcuts, pretty back end that a user will never see, flexing making their program 2% more efficient, etc. And almost none of them have released anything that anyone cares about. I am always thinking “holy shit how don’t they all see that they are simply wasting their time!”.  

The only reason I have found more success than them is because have I directed 100% of my effort towards getting my projects over the line and 0% on workflow, pretty code etc. 

BUT I have realized I am the total OPPOSITE side when it comes to music creation. And that’s probably why I haven’t yet had the success I have wanted!

 I am so guilty of always thinking about the next piece of gear or drum sample or guitar pickups that will get me “the sound I’m looking for” but I should be focusing my effort toward tangible goals like finishing 10 great songs this month or 50 great beats or whatever.

author: LAPhill
content:
I don't know why I didn't think of this sooner, but the closest parallel to the seismic shift of AI might be samples, even more so than things like digital recording or Pro Tools. When Hans Zimmer recorded an orchestra and started writing music with a DAW and showing clients mockups, nothing was ever the same. For a long time (even now!) the pencil-and-paper people griped about how it wasn't real composition. Orchestras feared that they would all be replaced by computers. But ultimately, everyone had to come to terms with the new world order and adapt. There was a period in the mid-90s through mid-late 2000s where orchestral writing was reduced to nothing more than long notes and short notes. All of the nuance was gone, because the tech couldn't handle it yet and people blamed the tech. Many mourned the loss of true orchestral writing, yearning for a by-gone era. 

But eventually, people learned to harness these new tools and they met the technology on its own terms. People are doing wildly innovative things with samples now, we've moved completely past the era of "can I make a convincing clarinet come out of my keyboard?" Orchestras and live musicians have not been replaced. Sure, the process is different than it used to be, but that's how innovations work. All of us would be living very different lives without samples of drums, guitars, orchestras, synths, etc. There will be a generation coming up where AI is already a thing, they won't have ever lived in the before-times. Just like those here who've never cut to tape. It's okay.

author: Slow Hand
content: My default outputs were always  *Mon L* and *Mon R*. If you change them to *Virtual 1* and *Virtual 2* then your output channels become a channel in *Console* that you can put plugin instances on, allowing you to put an EQ on your monitor path.

author: LAPhill
content:
To add on to the great advice being shared, keep in mind that the work of caring doesn't only happen when you're in the thick of it. If you get to the finish line and think "I wish that snare was punchier," or "We got there, but I'm not sure that mic was the best call in that situation," you can still experiment after the fact.

I've found that no matter how much time and effort I put in, when a project is over, there are new questions and things I want to try. So I might take a day a few weeks later, when it's slow, and shoot out some compressor plug-ins, or try to dial in a bass tone better than I achieved at the time. 

Figuring those things out when it's slow lets me be more efficient and focused when I'm head-down on a project.

author: Oli J
content:
My standard mix deliverables are…

- Main, instrumental, acapella, TV (lead vocal muted)
- Cleans of above where applicable
- Grouped stems (drums, bass, vocals etc) including cleans - vocals wet and dry
- Separate stems (every track solo and bounced through mix bus) including clean versions 
- Committed pro tools mix session (final mix session with all plugins committed) + cleans

author: cian riordan
content: This is something where you need to figure out your own path. There are certain rules you can go by, but if you're just starting out, I would forego metering and start wrapping your head around some reference tracks. If you're able, have another track (that you know translates well) that's in stylistic ballpark of the song you're working on play out of a separate set of inputs. If you can toggle between your mix and the reference on a monitor controller, this is the best. There's a plugin called Metric AB that you can put on your master buss that will help as well. Then set the level of your reference track to 0dBFS so it's playing back full volume, and try and work your mix up to that level of 'loudness'. You're not necessarily trying to ape the sonic characteristics of the reference, but it will help guide you in making decisions throughout the mix process that add to the overall sense of volume. This will be much more insightful than chasing a single LUFS value or having a bunch of analyzers.

author: Skyler Young
content:
If it feels right it is right. 

I used to think I needed the perfect plug-in chain and presets that my favorite mixer used for something to sound good. But when I tried that I was stunned that it didn’t seem right. It took me ages to realize that whatever makes the music feel better is better, no need to over intellectualize it. It doesn’t matter if x mixer used it, if it doesn’t feel right it’s not right. 

I had to learn to apply this to personal relationships. Sometimes relationships (romantic and non-romantic) seem perfect on paper but when you consistently feel worse after spending time with someone it doesn’t matter if you can’t intellectualize it, they are not the people you should be around anymore. If it feels good to be around someone it is good to be around them. If it doesn’t feel good them it’s not good to be around them. Simple as that - stop trying to overthink it.

Trying to navigate software versions and licenses -- not to mention linking sample libraries --  on someone else's machine is a nightmare. Bringing your computer is always the easiest way. If you're in Pro Tools, do yourself a favor and export the studios I/O settings into a file before you power down and swap over. That's my hot take.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I went to help a fellow engineer buddy record some drums today at his studio, and it made me think of something Jon Castelli said on the Conversations or LWMR podcast - he challenged the idea of being out of your comfort zone to grow, and look at the Benefits of the comfort zone.

My buddy is a great engineer and great drummer in a great and, so all great things. But his setup was just incredibly different than mine; he uses Studio One, I use pro tools (he’s also used to Pro tools and recently bailed on it). He’s using a combo of Antelope Discrete 8 and an Audient ASP880 and some good outboard pres (Vintech and Summit audio). His monitoring killed me, some small dynaudios which sounded okay and some ProAc’s. He had some decent mics. I brought my 8 Channels of UTA and a bunch of mics and was there just to put our heads together, and I was going mostly press record so he could drum for his bands record.

Anyway, we spent about 4+ hours trouble shooting Studio One, his computer, and the interfaces -eventually finding out one of his AD/DA channels was so messed up it sounded like a ribbon mic when it was a condenser. A lot of his mic stands and cables were really junky - he didn’t have enough of the basics on his own.

So many things were just not working as I would expect - my UTA preamps were set at much lower gains than I do at my studio because of his gear. I’m basically ear-blind because of the monitoring, even with headphones, and I’m working in Studio One so I can barely focus on the sound. And he used a normal Apple mouse, I use a trackball. 

Im trying not to complain, but it just blew my mind how much of an uphill battle recording can be just because of simple things being so taxing. We spent about an hour of the 6 hours I was there tracking one song. The rest was setup. It made me realize why we put so much work into making our process simple and getting gear that is effective and reliable.

author: Slow Hand
content:
You could make it a point to turn the screen off when you want them to focus on the listening. Keep the metering out of sight.

It's worth keeping in mind that if they're new students they're also integrating a *lot* of new knowledge all at once. Not just the concept you're trying to teach (let's say compression, for example). 

Not only are they trying to understand the concept you're explaining, but they'll want to know how you opened up the plugin window, what the key command is, what plugin type you're choosing, what the exact name is, and what channel you're putting it on. They may be learning the software at the same time, which is a whole other mindset to juggle.

Perhaps the solution is to clearly state what they should be focused on, and once they listen without using their eyes, then you can repeat it with the monitor on and show them *also* how to set up and use the tool. Reassure them that for now they can let go of trying to figure out the DAW (for example) and then you will double back around and demonstrate the implementation.

author: LAPhill
content:
Jumping in way late to this conversation, but some thoughts:

I'm broadly on board with @Rollmottle 's sentiments that no one is owed anything, especially in this line of work. That said, all music industry professionals, from mastering engineers to songwriters to musicians, increasingly are in a place where they need to prove why they're worth a premium cost. Premium is no longer newbie engineer vs. Serban, it's free plugins (or the artist's friend with a laptop full of cracked software) vs someone with reps at all. Maybe right now, the "premium" cost of engineering is minimum wage, but that is sadly still much more expensive than slapping CLA vocal and Ozone on your track with well-produced Splice loops. So why is your service worth more than that? It's an honest question that we all face.

I believe in the value of educating a client in why what we do costs what it does, but I'm not going to lose sleep over someone that can't see it. I see a ton of up-and-comers over valuing their worth and losing out on gigs because they don't understand how far they have to go. Engineers are often just as guilty at overvaluing themselves as artists are at undervaluing them. 

The one thing that does seem to still hold true in 2023 is that people that are doing consistently good work keep getting hired. And track records of reliability, decent (not even great!) work, and some credits that someone's heard of are all things to point to when talking about price. @Deleted User made a point of someone wanting him, but not seeing his value, and that's a particularly tough spot. Sometimes, you've just got to walk away from those people, as good as it feels to be in demand by someone.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Quite a bit.

My learning is less music-focused these days, but I budget a lot of time for self-development and continued study.

Sometimes it's  20 min a day in a technical book that I'm reading. I move slowly and make sure I understand before I move on. It may take two months to complete, but I'm steady with it and I do a little bit most days. It's common for me to transcribe notes from high-density talks that I want to learn from and revisit them often over the span of a week. I'm constantly printing out my notes and reading material so that they're easy to revisit throughout the week.

I'm currently taking a project management course through MIT, which has been great. It's uncommon for me to do formal schooling these days, but this is work related and a direct application to my future capabilities that we thought would be beneficial for the company.

When I buy a new plugin (rare) I set aside time to go through it and turn every knob and try each feature to see what it's capable of. Learning a tool on the spot is a good way to kill the creative flow, so I do the exploration up-front when possible.

Often I'll have ideas for novel ways to use a tool (layering distortion, for example) and I'll set aside two hours to explore it and see what I find.

That said, I think my day-to-day may be quite different from a lot of folks here. My eggs aren't all in the business and pressures of record production, and so I rarely find myself buried in such commitments. I tend to keep "normal" business hours these days and keep a hard separation between my commitments and my leisure.

In fact I'd say that I'm actively structuring my life so that I can retain my leisure and don't find myself overwhelmed with commitments. That's a whole other story, though.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I’ve got a similar but different hack for A/B’ing between a reference on my Ableton template without the need for multiple outputs:

I drag my reference track or rough mix onto a muted *Reference* channel and set up a hotkey that does two things when I press it:

1) It solo’s the reference track and...

2) It bypasses all of the master buss processing on my master buss. So that the *Reference* isn’t being processed when I solo it.

Boom. Instant A/B referencing in Ableton.

author: Adam Thein
content:
My main tip for using Live live is try and replace as many third party plugins as you possibly can with stock, freeze as much as you can, and most of the latency you experience is going to be coming from internal delay compensation vs I/O latency.  If you are able to optimize your sets as much as possible, you can probably get away with running everything without offloading DSP to a UAD system.  If you are already in that ecosystem by all means!

I built a live set similar to what you have going based off of Daniel Mintseris Lynda (now LinkedIn Learning) videos that were amazingly helpful.  Also in my case I made samplers whenever possible of 3rd party synths if the patch didn't have a ton of modulation internally.  But yeah bottom line is keep an eye on your total device latency on groups (hovering over a group will display the total delay compensation/latency calculation in the Status Bar).

If you have any other questions for me feel free to DM!

Edit: we used a rackmount X32 for in ears that also served double duty as the audio interface running 16 i/o at 48khz and were able to do it on a 2015 macbook with minimal latency

author: Slow Hand
content:
Strongly second all of this. Watch your accumulated plugin latency like a miserly hawk and do what you can to use Ableton stock plugins when you can because they are incredibly stable within the DAW and the last think you want is A) for your session to crash during a show and B) you don't want to be troubleshooting a fussy set that was working fine yesterday when you have to be onstage in 15 minutes. That'll make you sweat bullets for sure. Been there.

Also *yes* to the Daniel Mintseris Ableton live set videos. If you're seriously considering using Ableton on stage with live instruments it's rich in strategies for streamlining an elaborate performance set.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Honestly on pure sonics AT graph is still the best sounding to me, and if Im on a song with a great singer and a great take and just need to tweak a word or two I’ll just audio suite it and call it a day. 

To answer an above question I just bounce out a 2 track instrumental, and import that into Melo as ref track up top, set the tempo, import however many stacks of vocals and get to work.  When doing it this way MD  stand-alone has the edge over the plug-in because it’s all right there in front of me. It’s easy to visually reference a quad tracked lead vocal, and then align and de ess or consonant 8 harmonies. That’s where the stand-alone really shines, is massively dense stacks vocals like that, and not having to keep opening up a plug-in to change a different part or vibrato or formant of a particular track  of the stack or what not. Especially once you get the groove locked in on the lead, it’s just so easy to make all other 30 tracks lock in with it. 

For a solo vocal soul song? I’m probably just audio suiting AT in graph mode in PT. It ultimately sounds the best.

author: peterlabberton
content: Personally, I don't really bother taking these kinds of notes while tracking. If I'm producing something myself, I prefer to just keep moving and try something, then move on as quickly as possible. If it needs to be redone for some reason, I'll just cook up a sound again and not get too hung up on whether it's identical or not—chances are if we're revisiting it, things could be improved anyway. If I'm engineering for someone else, I'll defer to them, but these are usually situations where things are even *more* time-sensitive (i.e. we're renting an expensive studio), and the situation is very unlikely to be recreated anyway. I was very lucky to have subbed in for @cian riordan with St. Vincent for a couple months in the early stages of this new record—nothing was documented (unless I grabbed a quick photo to cover my own ass), it was all just trying stuff, and if it worked it worked, if not, move on and forget it! Mixing is another story—in the (increasingly) rare instance when I'm mixing on a console, I'll figure out some way of recalling for that particular project. This is usually more or less @Rollmottle's method, except I go even more jank-ass and just scribble song names on a post-it and hold it in front of a piece of gear like a mugshot. Anything on the console is either stored in the console automation, or, like the most recent project I mixed on a console, I'll just calibrate all the faders and run stuff through it, but really *mix* in Pro Tools still. 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: cian riordan
content: That's super annoying. But being honest, I do see the reason that plug-in manufacturers would want a system like this, especially a company that's been doing it as long as Waves. If you bought a Waves plugin 15 years ago, how long are they expected to provide support for the one time purchase? Given that operating systems and DAW updates are always going to provide a moving target, it doesn't seem unreasonable to have some sort of upgrade fee or plan for them to cover their costs in the development of updated software. I just think with Waves, their whole pricing model is on drugs and it's hard to attain any semblance of sanity from their upgrade plans.

author: alecdibell2
content: @cian riordan yeah i agree, especially with the 15 year thing. The update plans are annual now though, so it would have to be renewed annually if your OS was being updated with each release ( at least from my experience). I ran into that issues after one or two years with those plugins. But honestly I don’t mind. I’m really happy with the plugins I’ve subbed in to replace what I used in the past. My main tools are the MCDSP channel strip, some fabfilter plugins, soundtoys bundle, UAD, and a few other things here and there. I think Waves marketing convinced me to buy tools I really didn’t need. But as a beginner at the time, plugin manufacturers can be pretty deceiptful in their marking strategy in my opinion. It wasn’t until after buying a bunch of different things, that I realized what tools I truly needed long term.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Just got this same spec also last weekend.  About a week in, it's definitely a little crowded for finishing work in my opinion but I'm use to working on a 1440p 24" monitor.  I can always HDMI I figure if I need the extra real estate.

The only acustica plug I run regularly is Ruby 2 - seems to cause pretty drastic spikes on the CPU short term in Ableton (running rosetta mode and VST3 by the way) but then it levels out.  In general I've been super impressed with the performance vs my desktop.  I'd say for my mixes it runs maybe 80% as well on large projects (75+ tracks, lots of processing) which was more than I was expecting.  Smaller projects and productions and softsynths it absolutely chews through compared to my desktop.

Was just trying out a little mix in Studio One just on the 14" and it felt very cramped to me.  I think it'd be hard to completely mix at this resolution but again it probably has more to do with what I'm used to.  Would definitely recommend a separate display if you are going to be doing all your work on it.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
When I was doing more prod, I had an ableton template that split my drum rack out onto audio channels, labelled “Drum 01, 02, 03…”. Any that were used would get a “kick, snare” etc label. 

When I got to a point with a beat where it was sounding good/I felt I was done, I’d do an “export all individual tracks”, then just delete any of the unused drum tracks. Obviously kept all the instruments too, this was just the idiosyncratic part for separating drums. 

Hey presto, couple hundred MB folder in a world of terabytes. Takes the same time as bouncing a mix in ableton.

In other quasi-AI developments, there's some pretty insane tech going on in the latest Unreal Engine demo: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dj60HHy-Kqk

About halfway through, they show some tools for moving elements around and the engine intelligently fills in the gaps and hooks it back into the environment seamlessly. Fun . Can dig it . I’ve got a 90s midi style production setup alongside my contemporary one . Akai s3000 slaves to the MPC 2000 . Into mixer . 
Only major difference to writing in the daw is timing of the mpc. Be aware if you’re tracking it into your daw it won’t line up on the grid as its timing drifts . I wasted a bit of time trying to work out the problem then slaving the mpc to daw MTC which then just removes the mpc swing which is counterproductive . So yeah , if at any point it’s gonna be tracked into the daw familiarise and strategise for that asap in the process .

author: Slow Hand
content:
I can understand the trepidation here. Now that Canva own Affinity, it's not yet clear what their strategy is. My guess is that there are a few reasons for this play:

1. Affinity Studio is now a loss leader for Canva's other offerings, like their (just announced) supplemental AI tool set or their enterprise plans, which I suspect are a big portion of their income compared to their Affinity suite licenses.

2. It eats into Adobe's market share. Making a very competitive alternative to Adobe's flagship software and then offering it for free encourages adoption by users who are ready to jump ship from their Adobe subscriptions or who need software like this and are fine without Adobe's cutting-edge tools (like me).

There are some positive examples of high-level *free* software that is continues to thrive with no sign of being abandoned, or compromised. Like DaVinci Resolve or Reaper (which is effectively free). There are also some great examples of open source software getting a new lease on life by their steward companies. Namely Musescore and Audacity's recent revamps. 

Now Affinity isn't open source, but Musegroup have a large full-time development team that seem to be getting by just fine developing what is effectively free software. If they can do it, then Affinity likely can.

Here's hoping Canva have done the math right before setting out on this course.

author: antoniohannamusic
content:
Hey Rob, so I did a video explaining it (using the older version of the plugin) but in short you create two sessions, an Artist Session and a Producer Session.

The Producer session: Sends full mix + click to artist and has a receive channel

The Artist Session:

Receives full mix, then sends back the performance dry (vocal, guitar, bass, trumpet, you name it)>

In the producer session you then offset your local playback by the roundtrip latency, so you're hearing the artist perform "in time" with your session,

You then just nudge the clips back after each take 😄

author: Dodgy
content: Also, is there a particular level I should set the mic gain on the interface? It seems like it comes in really low. Is it better to record low and boost in DAW or increase mic gain (phantom power is on, a lot of my songs are softer delivery)

author: cian riordan
content: In a space that small, as much absorption as you can have will help you. Do you have a bigger room to record in or do you need the isolation? You'll likely get better sonic results if you can find a room with some more volume... that will also allow you to play with position in front of the microphone. As far as the level you should record at, if you've got any half-decent mic pre than you can go into the computer pretty conservatively. Assuming you don't have a super noisy chain, there'll be plenty of headroom in a 24 bit recording to bring it up after the fact. If you're looking for numbers, I'd shoot to get things into your DAW at around -18 dBFS. Many of the plugins modeled after analog gear tend to be happier with that level (or less if you're unsure).

author: cian riordan
content: Yes, exactly. There's no real benefit in trying to get a 'hot' signal directly into your computer... so anything totally clear of clipping should work fine. If you're in Pro Tools, you can right click the meter (any meter) and change it to RMS mode if that's useful.  Try and stay out of the yellow, and definitely out of the orange/red.

author: David Fuller
content:
Anyway: uncompressed PCM audio (.wav and .aiff) is made up of digital words generally 16 or 24 bits long recorded however many times a second for a given sample rate, for fixed point (integer) values. Each bit represents ~6dB of dynamic range. Every time you go up in level 6dB from that particular sample point, another bit flips from 0 (off) to 1 (on). The least significant bit defines your noise floor, so 16 bit audio has 96dB of dynamic range at maximum from noise floor to full scale (every bit turned on). Seems simple enough, right? And it isn't super complicated. But it has one problem: you run out of dynamic range real quick if you're changing levels with (virtual) faders at 24 bits. There are two ways around that:
1, make the mixer engine run on a much higher integer word length (like old Pro Tools HD systems, which use 48 bit integer), and the mixer automatically converts the audio (if anything is done to it, including fader moves) to 48 bit. Think of this as adding more digits to the fractions side of a decimal point. 
2, make the mixer engine run on a floating point system (almost every other DAW, including more modern versions of Pro Tools) - that is, you move *where the decimal point is* . 32 bit float effectively works as 24 bits that can be moved around more or less with impunity, up or down.

author: dylannash
content:
What are some of your favourite elements of your prod/mix templates? I currently have a separate production/writing template and then another for mixing but I’m trying to hybridise and streamline them a little more to get faster results and hopefully focus on the song. Also, most of the songs I mix tend to be one’s I’ve written and produced as well, so hoping to cut down on session set-up time.

Some of mine are an instant “duck bus”, which I picked up from Ian Kirkpatrick. It’s a pre-loaded aux with something like LFO Tool or shaper box on it, so you can quickly route and uniformly make things side chain.

Another quick workflow thing I love is having Pro Tools audio playlists with a bunch of reverse sweeps, impacts and other transition fx/ear candy hidden and ready to go in the session, so you can quickly try out a bunch. 

I also have the trim plugin added as the first and last plugin on every new track preset, as I use them to quickly manage the gain in and out of each track and so I don’t have to search for them constantly.

Ozone Spectral shaper on some music busses and as a replacement for Soothe on the mix bus has also been a real win (thanks Jon!) Although these sorta things aren’t turned on whilst writing as they have a ton of latency.

Keen to hear what you all find useful!

author: Slow Hand
content: Yeah. It's a major move for Apple. It's comparable to their switch in 2005 when they transitioned from Power PC chips to the Intel line (which are now being phased out). We're in a transition period now as Apple updates all of their hardware to these new purpose-built chips. Now all of the software developers (Avid, Ableton, FabFilter, whoever) have to rewrite a lot of their software before they can function reliably on the new chips. Some companies have already transitioned successfully while bigger ones have a lot of work to get caught up on.

author: Zack Hames
content: Do you have any way of recording at home? You mention "while you are not actually recording". The best way to practice is to literally do it as often as possible even if it's by yourself. You won't train the social aspect, you won't really train problem solving of an external source (a guitarist with a particularly shitty amp or playing technique per-say), but you can certainly experiment endlessly on capturing sounds. Shootouts, micing techinques, it's pretty much endless. If you don't have a recording setup at home or are in an apartment where you can't be as loud as you'd want, I try to absorb as much information as I can. Podcasts (Andrew Talks to Awesome People / Unstoppable Recording Machine / Working Class Audio / Conversations Audio), Online articles, (Sound on Sound) GearSpace Forum Q+A, TapeOp interviews, Youtube Series (Making Records with EV, Sounds-Like-a-Drum), etc. These can be incredibly inspiring and keep your mind tuned into the recording process.  I sort of use this as my "fix" when I am not able to work actively on a project. Otherwise, what everyone else has said about mixing are perfect suggestions. Maybe set limitations like only using plugins you haven't used. or remove a plugin you are constantly using to force yourself out of a habit. Practice editing dramatically even if the track doesn't call for it so you can get your editing chops up.

it's great to be mobile and move everywhere. i do keep my vintage 87 with me at all times, so i have a solid vocal chain anywhere (apollo x preamp is more than good enough with the 87). the challenge is headphones, and i haven't found a solution that replaces speakers. i've tried some different open back headphones (grados, focal clear mg) but they don't have the "oomph" that i get from speakers. the imaging and clarity is better than my ath m50x headphones i always have, but the lack of big bass and the annoyance of open back (can't really use in public, on planes, etc) make them not really useful to me.

author: timwatt_
content:
Pretty basic question but how do you guys archive production/songwriting sessions?

An artist wants to use a production of mine from 2017 and when I opened up the session to run off the multitrack many of the plugins didn’t load. I’ve been able to download/upgrade/fix most of the heavy movers but some can’t be installed on the current OS. Main culprits are the original Neutron and Vocalsynth (which I was using a lot at the time).

I figure that in this situation I’m going to have to recreate some sounds (which is fine as I’ll be reproducing some of the more dated elements anyway) but it got me thinking about future proofing sessions going forward. It’s made me even consider not using certain plugins in my productions if it’s likely they won’t be supported in the future (*cough* izotope).

I’m sure the solution is as simple as ‘print a multitrack when done’ but if anyone has any other thoughts I’m all ears!

author: Slow Hand
content:
Very lightly.

Red = ‘Needs resolution’ or ‘To Do’
Yellow = ‘In progress’ or ‘worth remembering’
Green = ‘Complete’ or ‘Final’

I rarely do this for individual files. It’s more for project folders like Ableton sessions. My *Song Sessions* folder is full of projects where I’m dicking around or doing a one-off thing and will never revisit, but if I sketch a song in an afternoon and it’s interesting enough that I may want to revisit it someday it’ll get a yellow dot so I can identify it as worth revisiting in the future.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Totally. That was exactly what I thought when exploring the AI DAW that Ruairi posted last night. "How is this any different than what we already do?" In both cases you still need to specify exactly what you want. At that point you may as well do it yourself, if you're capable.

If you're unable to specify exactly what you want then you're at the mercy of the AI or of an artisan who can interpret your requests. Whatever shape the future of recorded music takes it seems that there's still likely to be artisans steering the ship. Just in a different capacity. 

You still need someone with know-how and with taste to make the call.

Using it as a plugin vs stand-alone sounds different to my ears. At least the version I’m on. author: BatMeckley
content:
Yeah, I think if you like it as a plug-in that’s a totally reasonable opinion, but them using the same algo isn’t necessarily factual. Important to delineate the two. (And it’s been a few years, but it was an actual Celemony employee that told me this, and… my ears.)

Also, if you’re just in the e business of touching up a single lead vocal, go hard with the plug-in. author: WitnesstheLight
content: According to the manual of the SIR standardCLIP plug-in the highest oversampling option is 256x. This means that the plug-in will increase the sample rate of the signal by 256 times before clipping, and then filter out the unwanted frequencies above the original Nyquist frequency after clipping. This process reduces the distortion and aliasing caused by clipping, and improves the sound quality of the signal. 🤓

author: EliHeathMusic
content:
With credits, is there a general consensus or definition on the distinction between  "producer" and "additional production" or is it always a case by case thing? Had a song I worked on (finished the production and did the mix) come out today. At the beginning of the project I had asked to be listed as a producer and mixer but realized when it came out, that the artist had listed himself as the producer and me as additional production/instrumentation, and mixer. The artist is a really good and longtime friend and I am going to just talk to him and ask that he fixes the credits (and will start making written agreements before all of my projects) but I am curious if there is any broader context that could help how I approach the conversation? 

Not super critical to the main question but here are some specifics of my situation: Artist wrote the song, and recorded some basic tracks (drums, vox, guitar). We then worked on it in my studio and I played more instruments (bass, guitars, keys, lap, steel, percussion). We then finished it remotely a few months later. Sent the Ableton production session back and forth a few times times and then I prepped and exported the files myself and mixed it in Protools. And I had to do what I would consider a fair amount of heavy lifting in the mix: song was pretty complicated and recorded at home so I ended up do doing a lot of clean up, some tuning, and a lot of sound shaping and effects. All that to say, this case feels pretty cut and dried but I am curious to know what types of work would appropriately fall under “additional production” and what is standard in the industry. Thanks!

author: hank01564
content: For pro tools, there’s some huge work flow advantages with being able to record arm multiple tracks without their respective groups being enabled by alt clicking. Same for mute and solo without the alt click. Also doing volume automation there can be helpful so you maintain individual track volume freedom instead of locking it down to one automation lane while still seeing the automation represented in the track volume display. Unlike an aux, you can also disable it to A/B what it was before you added those layers of volume automation. Helpful for the “vocal ups, vocal downs, wait do it like it was before” while still being able to go back to the original with one click

author: wcalebparker
Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Snares or other sounds, I do have loose process that helps me move keep momentum and focus.

TLDR; It’s a contextual balancing act that takes both the context of the music and the studio environment into account.

Music Context

Phase 1 | Production
- 🔑 Everything will be refined later, so I focus on Momentum > Perfection.
- I feel the core energy of inspiration behind the track and go through sounds with the intention of finding one that captures the essence of the finished vision. Doesn’t matter if it’s excellent at this stage.

Phase 2 | Post-Production Mix
- 🔑 I revisit sounds with the intention to sculpt an emotionally enhancing space for the music to live in (small venue, living room, arena, efc).
- Refine sounds while keeping initial energy in mind, but you can focus more creativity on ‘mixing’ than ‘production’ (at least how my mind perceives them)
- Will likely need to replace a part of the snare stack, but now that more of the tracks vision has bridged the gap between vision to reality it’ll be easier to find a proper pocket and vibe for things. 
- Because that initial sound resonated with me, I’ll try plug-in sculpting before replacing, but I tend to add / replace the sound that emulates the rattle under the snare at this stage + add dimension for the emotional space I’m building.
- 🗒️ Sometimes a diff sample can come with these things off the bat no tweaking needed, its rare though.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm sure there's some amazing new tech out today, but the biggest bang for your buck that I know is an algorithm akin to what Ableton's *Beats* warp mode does:

1. Slice the audio file at each transient.
2. Globally apply fades to the end of each slice.

This has the effect of drying up the verb on each slice. That said, I'm sure it's effectiveness is very dependent on the source material.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
It does not. Many have done the null test.

DAW specific plugins, different warping algorithms, workflow differences, and some soft clipping differences account for the changes people hear.

If you have reasonable headroom and use the same plugins and use the same bit depth etc etc they are all the same.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
I’m late to this, but wanted to say my part that I navigate DAWs based on the mindset of the workflow I’m intending to get into.

If I needa hit a new track quick to get a vibe set, FL Studio is amazing for quick production and quickly transforming the studio into a different vibe, but if I need to do a bunch of vocal takes and/or deep mixing juggling chains and transforming that vibe into a captured piece, especially those meant to become a product, I find Pro Tools Ultimate the absolute 🐝s 🦵s for that.

-

They may have patched it and this is old news, but I know FL can’t handle as much CPU and it used to run off of one processor, so my quad processor CPU can’t handle more than 20 tracks in FL, whereas I can I have 200+ tracks on Pro Tools and still run smooth (utilizing freeze and stuff too, which FL doesn’t have) so yeah.

In the end, once a threshold of quality for a tool is passed, it’s a matter taste based preference, and I find my taste varying with projects and my two DAWs capture all the different intentions I find myself having between the two different UIs / Workflows

This was an interesting read. You should check out analog x ai.
